an4.41:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of developing immersion further.
an4.41:1.3: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in the present life.
an4.41:1.4: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision.
an4.41:1.5: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness.
an4.41:1.6: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements.
an4.41:2.1: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in the present life?
an4.41:2.2: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.
an4.41:2.3: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in the present life.
an4.41:3.1: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision?
an4.41:3.2: It’s when a mendicant focuses on the perception of light, concentrating on the perception of day,
an4.41:3.3: regardless of whether it’s night or day.
an4.41:3.4: And so, with an open and unenveloped heart, they develop a mind that’s full of radiance.
an4.41:3.5: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision.
an4.41:4.1: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness?
an4.41:4.2: It’s when a mendicant knows feelings as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.
an4.41:4.3: They know perceptions as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away. They know thoughts as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.
an4.41:4.4: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness.
an4.41:5.1: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements?
an4.41:5.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.
an4.41:5.3: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
an4.41:5.4: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.
an4.41:5.5: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.
an4.41:5.6: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
an4.41:5.7: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
an4.41:5.8: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements.
an4.41:5.9: These are the four ways of developing immersion further.
an4.41:5.10: And it was in this connection that I said in ‘The Way to the Beyond’, in ‘The Questions of Puṇṇaka’:
an4.41:6.1: ‘Having assessed the world high and low,
an4.41:6.2: they’re not shaken by anything in the world.
an4.41:6.3: Peaceful, unclouded, untroubled, with no need for hope,
an4.41:6.4: they’ve crossed over birth and old age, I declare.’”
